Legal_Issue: Residency requirement under s. 5(1)(c) of Citizenship Act
Application_Facts: Applicant: Qureshi; Judge disclosed anonymous letter and allowed response; Inconsistencies in applicant's evidence regarding residency
Decision_Outcome: Appeal dismissed; no order as to costs
Court_Ruling: No breach of procedural fairness; Residency determination was reasonable
Defendant_Behavior: Citizenship judge relied on anonymous letter but disclosed contents and allowed response
Procedural_Issue: Use of anonymous letter without proper disclosure
Credibility_Assessment: Inconsistencies in applicant's evidence undermined credibility
Application_Basis: Failure to meet three-year physical residence requirement within four years
Governing_Rule: Procedural fairness requires disclosure of adverse information; Residency mandate under Citizenship Act
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Inconsistent evidence on duration and pattern of residence
Harm_Assessment: No demonstrable harm due to fair process
Cause_Description: Qureshi appealed denial of citizenship application due to alleged procedural unfairness and residency requirement misapplication
Evidence_Handling: Contents of anonymous letter disclosed; opportunity to respond provided
Residency_Compliance: Not satisfied according to judge's assessment
Evidence_Assessment: Judge reasonably assessed evidence of residency
Decision_Rationale: Procedural fairness upheld due to disclosure; residency conclusion supported by evidence
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness for factual findings on residency
